'find x: x/4 = 2/8'

display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 548px; height: 1px; padding-top: 145px; margin-left: 131px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div:
Problem Shape
As a geometric shape, where variables are used to construct a shape reflecting the variables
Different formats of the variables can be assigned (like how 'connect' conveys a variable interaction but is more general than 'divide')
Different variable structures can be applied, like gaps, spectrums, sequences or simple sides of a shape. Progress can be marked by reducing the shape to its components.

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 38px; height: 1px; padding-top: 990px; margin-left: 76px;

div.div: X

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 58px; height: 1px; padding-top: 345px; margin-left: 706px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;
display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 392px; height: 1px; padding-top: 545px; margin-left: 469px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div:
Inferring X using squares indicating the corresponding connection between 2/8 where 4 is in the same position as 8 is a matter of identifying that 4 is half of 8, at which point inferring how long X should be is a matter of applying the same factor to 2.
Alternatively it can be solved structurally once in this format, by shrinking the 2x8 rectangle until the bottom is 4 and finding the other side at that point, once it's identified that they should retain the same ratio, meaning the shrink function should be applied to both sides.
If the area is frequently used in other calculations, it may be beneficial to format problems like this in this way, or using other common structures, while they don't violate definitions/rules.
Applying the intent interface is useful for identifying why this is an alternative to the original division operation. The intent of 'shrink' applied to a rectangle until a parameter change is applied is related to the 'division' operation as well as corresponding operations like 'halve', all of which involve reductions, connecting the intents they fulfill.
Alternatively, calculating that in this format, the smaller target rectangle would have 1/4th of the area is another useful function to apply to determine when to stop shrinking or the final output of the shrinking operations to avoid the iterative shrinking operations, which applies the inference methods of determining limits of the missing value in this format as is done with the number sequence format.

switch.text: Inferring X using squares indicating the corresponding connection...

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 457px; height: 1px; padding-top: 545px; margin-left: 1px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div:
This particular variable format applied to this problem is primarily only useful for tracking complexity of the remaining variables to resolve, but semantic mapping is required when the structures aren't exactly related like the sides of a shape. This format doesn't tell us how the variables are related or their data type, but there are opportunities to use a shape when some variables should share a connecting edge, as in graphs.
Similar to how applying x, 4, 2, and 8 as sides of related rectangles to the right requires ignoring the fact that the area is reduced by a factor of 4, which is irrelevant to the problem when solved that way. However it can be useful to keep the shape having the same side ratio when applying transforms to it to find X, and the area is related to side length in the same way that the side lengths are related to each other. (You can use the obvious factor of 4 between areas as a way of calculating X once in that format where the difference in area is obvious, or you can use the factor of 2 representing the difference in side lengths once in that format.
This format is more useful for describing limits of a value to be computed as the solution value, such as how computing that x is greater than 0, less than 2, and an integer are coordinating factors that provide a limited search space that can be formatted as a 3-variable shape. However the variables aren't necessarily semantically organizable as sides of a 3-d shape like the ratios are as sides of rectangles, which preserve the ratio in a useful way when shrunk in a 1-1 ratio (shrinking both sides by the same factor to preserve the original side length ratio), so finding corresponding equivalent alternate ratios like smaller variants of the ratio is possible by shrinking the rectangle, which other shapes might not provide as a useful semantic mapping for that particular problem.

switch.text: This particular variable format applied to this problem is primarily only us...

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 98px; height: 1px; padding-top: 1015px; margin-left: 141px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div: Divide by 2

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 348px; height: 1px; padding-top: 1135px; margin-left: 26px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div:
How do you format the variables in this format to begin with?
First you need to identify that there is a similar function (division or just a general connection function) applied that connects some variables (x,4 and 2,8).
Then you need to identify that there is a way to derive one known corresponding value (4) from another (8), and that this direction of derivation is useful to apply to another position (deriving x from 2), since x is the value to identify and the similarity between these ratios holds for the numerator position.
This can be formatted as a network, but also as a set of interfaces representing connections which form a foundation for other changes.

switch.text: How do you format the variables in this format to begin wi...

Even
(multiple)
attribute

div.div: As a variable variable network (connecting attributes of variables), applying interface structures like reductions to differences to remove irrelevant differences and make similarities and connections and differences in the remaining differences more obvious.

switch.text: As a variable variable network (connecting attributes of...

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 182px; height: 1px; padding-top: 955px; margin-left: 706px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div: By reducing the 'even' attribute, we are checking if there are any multiples can be reduced to 1, which would make differences between numbers more obvious (1/4 is a more obvious difference than 2/8)

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 348px; height: 1px; padding-top: 1185px; margin-left: 469px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div: This applies useful structures like attributes such as 'multiples' to reduce differences that are irrelevant between structures, which incidentally equalizes the original equation in this simple problem, leading to an exact equivalence by applying one difference reduction. This is the process of standardization done in interface analysis that makes important differences more obvious, so would be part of an interface query in many cases, like a query to find 'structural similarities' like that between multiples of the same ratio.

switch.text: This applies useful structures like attributes such as 'mu...

Ratio
attribute

div.div: As a function network (creating variables of variables), composed of useful functions like core interaction functions such as connect/reduce/filter, which can work like an attribute network to apply differences to connect variables, where the useful functions are in different positions than the useful attributes, like how a variable/attribute network would likely have more nodes than a useful function network as the same functions would be repeated more frequently than the same attributes.

switch.text: As a function network (creating variables of variables),...

box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;

div.div: Repeat until all useful differences are identified.

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 63px; height: 1px; padding-top: 1368px; margin-left: 84px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div: Reduce differences

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 68px; height: 1px; padding-top: 1365px; margin-left: 279px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div: Identify irrelevant differences

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 333px; height: 1px; padding-top: 1285px; margin-left: 56px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div: As a useful structure network, where frequently useful structures like 'function sequences' are applied by default.

switch.text: As a useful structure network, where frequently useful s...

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 348px; height: 1px; padding-top: 1635px; margin-left: 49px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div:
The irrelevant differences applied in this function sequence are differences that it's not important to retain, such as differences in values, when trying to equalize values, and when the differences can be applied uniformly, such as to both sides of a ratio, which doesn't remove the important information of the core ratio difference, merely reduces it to a unit value.
This is like if you had neural networks that were useful in different ways for solving high-variation problems, and you put them together in an ensemble to try to decrypt all of the variation in your inputs. These useful function sequences are the most useful structures to solve problems, so putting them in a network (to run interface queries on just the useful function sequences) is additively useful.

switch.text: The irrelevant differences applied in this function sequen...

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 58px; height: 1px; padding-top: 1275px; margin-left: 395px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div: Remainder of network

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 58px; height: 1px; padding-top: 835px; margin-left: 390px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div: Remainder of network

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 58px; height: 1px; padding-top: 1065px; margin-left: 1065px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div: Remainder of network

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 93px; height: 1px; padding-top: 1785px; margin-left: 346px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;
display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 758px; height: 1px; padding-top: 2155px; margin-left: 26px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div:
In the set of solutions in the format of 'adjacent combinations of direct input variables', what filters might be useful?
An adjacent combination such as "find the factor to multiply each variable to connect it with another variable", which would produce such possible solution function steps as:
2 * z = 8, x * z = 4
4 * y = 8, x * y = 2
These systems of equations are useful to solve in a sequence, and are easily derived from simple change combinations of direct input variables, and importantly are equivalent interchangeable alternates (you only have to solve one system of these equations, not both).
Applying core interface structures like 'adjacent change combinations' to fulfill common problem-solving intents like 'generate a set of possible solutions (or solution structures like solution steps)' would create a set of function sets that could be useful when solvable together as a system of equations, or a set of functions that can be more useful when applied in a sequence.
How would you filter out the less useful functions generated by your function which generates 'adjacent change combinations', and only select the two above as useful systems of equations to apply together?
For example, your generation function would also identify simple combinations like: 2 * x = 8, x * y = 4
How would you automatically identify these as less useful/relevant to your problem of finding the value of x?
This change combination creates a non-definitively connected set of variables (x/8) which are not definitely adjacently connected in the set of ratios that is the original problem format, but this combination treats that connection as definitive and direct, which violates the structures (and their definitions and interaction rules) being applied. X may be related to 8 in many ways but those are irrelevant except where 8 is first connected to its corresponding similar structure (4) which then has a direct connection to x.
How would you identify that the sequence where y is solved for first and then applied in an equation to find x is a more useful sequence than the opposite direction?
X is the value to find, so finding an interim connecting value (y) which connects the direct input variables (2, 4, 8) with the direct output variable (x) is useful to complete that sequence of connections.
These adjacent combinations of simple functions and direct input variables are particularly useful in this simple problem, but in more complex problems could still be useful as components, however more direct components would possibly be more useful to derive in more complex problems on a more adjacent interaction level that 'adjacent change combinations'.
How would you identify these solution filters ("find function sequences where x is the last value calculated since it's the target solution output (apply requirements)", "find function sequences where rules/definitions are not violated or implied but explicit and definitive (apply definitions)", "find systems of equations (function sets) which are relevant by applying adjacent change combinations (apply core interface structures like components/combinations)") as particularly useful in a set of all possible solution filters?
Ultimately, they capture a high degree of variation and capture a high ratio of relevant variation in problems. They also apply common structures like combinations and apply problem-solving structures like requirements/definitions, but that is incidental compared to the fact that they capture maximal variation, which is a core structure that decomposes problem-solving in general.
Additional filters could filter out a set of three equations, since two is enough to solve this problem, applying filters to match complexity level of the problem with the complexity level of the solution function sequence.
These filters could be a part of a 'solution filter network', similar to the other networks above, after applying a 'solution generation network' to identify possible solutions or solution components/steps or other solution structures like solution step sequences.

switch.text: In the set of solutions in the format of 'adjacent combinations of direct input variables', what filters might be useful?...

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 538px; height: 1px; padding-top: 465px; margin-left: 1249px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div:
Other problems might be more complicated and would look like a complex shape like a "Calabi-Yau manifold" when the problem variables are mapped to a shape without violating the problem structure definitions/rules and without adding unnecessary information.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Calabi%E2%80%93Yau_manifold
Or a network might be a better decomposition structure, outside of geometric shapes. Mixing these different spaces (geometry, networks) is possibly useful but hasn't been explored sufficiently to know which mixes are useful.
For example, is there a variable network that decrypts many complex geometric shapes, with variables like 'overlaps/intersections' or 'loop filling' and 'angle sequence generators' as nodes on the network?
Structures like this which connect the math and system or structure interfaces are probably a useful priority to focus on. For example, could an extremely different structure that is still cohesive and stable enough to be useful to model the 'maximally different structure' that decomposes most problems with a simple query/traversal of the structure?
What other structures could decompose a high degree of variation in a structure other than a network? (Sankey chart, Voronoi diagram, topologies, etc) Is applying these structures in the same structure additively useful (applying Sankey charts as a map, applying Voronoi diagrams as a way of identifying similar shapes) to model the highest-variation connections (or alternatives like the most common inputs of highest-variation connections)?
These cross-interface structures (such as "mixing geometric shapes with requirements and logic functions") are likelier to be useful in connecting different problem formats and therefore solving problems in general.
The interface network in general is so far the most useful high variation-capturing structure, which makes useful information the most obvious and trivial to find, but finding cross-interface (such as 'geometric') patterns in the interface network (such as a 'system layer diagram of useful function sequences' or a 'perspective network of problem shape rotations') is additively useful.

switch.text: Other problems might be more complicated and would look like a complex shape like a "Calab...

Problem Maps
(as alternatives to networks and interfaces)

div.div: Rotating the cylinder until it seems like a circle is useful when it is likely that a function to derive the volume of the cylinder from the radius will be useful or if the volume is useful to obscure for some reason.

div.div: Similarly, rotating this problem format until you're viewing it from the center draws a clear similarity between the ratio numerator and denominator by first identifying the sub-interface connecting them (the symmetry of the equivalence =), at which point, rotating one operation (division) and applying it to the corresponding structures of the other side is trivial.

div.div: Applying changes to problem/solution structures is useful in cases such as where another structure like another solution format is useful, such as how a 'probable solution prediction function range and some contradictory data points to retain' is a better format to compress the original data set than a solution prediction function on its own.

display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 28px; height: 1px; padding-top: 415px; margin-left: 1153px;

div.div: Shrink (a rectangle to match factors of equal ratios)

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 278px; height: 1px; padding-top: 590px; margin-left: 920px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div:
Altering the angle connecting the two number line sequences is another way to calculate the connection between the two ratios in a different way than factorization of the known ratio (denominator) applied to the unknown ratio (numerator).
Another method would be applying inference to deduce the missing value by identifying requirements of its value given connections with surrounding interactive structures like values that it couldn't be, limits on its value, etc, by inferring rules like "it must be greater than zero' and 'it must be less than 2' and 'given that 2 is even, x must be an integer given the even factor between the denominators', as applying these rules indicates a non-zero, integer between 0 and 2, which would indicate x = 1.

switch.text: Altering the angle connecting the two number l...

div.div: Basic shape (structure facts as limits of a problem)

switch.text: Basic shape (structure facts as limits of a probl...

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 276px; height: 1px; padding-top: 3765px; margin-left: 282px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; font-weight: bold; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div: Applying Useful Structures across Problems

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 638px; height: 1px; padding-top: 3965px; margin-left: 105px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div:
Some structures are useful and general enough to apply across problems, like cost-benefit analysis, and differences in structures that are useful to compare like intended functionality vs. requirements/limits, where gaps in between these two objects represent a possible error space and a method of reducing the errors by eliminating the gaps (such as where gaps between functionality and limits in biological systems allows errors like cancer, where applying limits might correct such errors, or where gaps between code and limits in code bases allows errors like malicious usages of code to occur, where reducing that gap between code and limits could reduce this type of error.)
Other problem dichotomies are useful to compare and offer a default implementation method/intent to aim for, where applying structure to one item indicating a certainty allows and enables revelation and resolution of the other which represents the uncertainty.
Similarly applying useful interface structures to functions like matrix multiplication in neural networks can integrate useful structures such as where increasing/decreasing or dropping a value can be enhanced by interface structures like averages or thresholds, to find patterns like 'returning to average' or 'crossing a threshold' in variable changes which offer useful insights for future changes that can allow other operations like 'skipping an increase/decrease operation'.
Similarly useful structures like 'interactive structures' can fulfill some problem-solving core interaction functions like 'build' as knowing which structures are interactive allows assembly of these structures, applying them as components, which is an alternative to identifying input-output sequences as components of problem-solution connection functions.
Similarly, useful structures like 'common problem-solving functions or solution variables' as a network, topology, or other structure to traverse when generating different solutions or solution-finding methods is a way to benefit from known structures like variables of solutions and the limits/averages of these variables.

switch.text: Some structures are useful and general enough to apply across problems, like cost-benefit analysis, and di...

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 210px; height: 1px; padding-top: 3155px; margin-left: 319px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; font-weight: bold; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div:
Problem Applications/Embeddings
(providing systems/contexts where a problem is neutralized)

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 638px; height: 1px; padding-top: 3245px; margin-left: 105px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div:
Applying a problem as an input can be useful in cases where this will resolve some variable, such as how different the input is from what would qualify as a useful structure or a solution structure.
For example, applying a known incorrect or suboptimal function in place of the optimal function can give error information about how different the incorrect/suboptimal function is from a correct/optimal function, and can provide information about cases where that problem could be a solution to a different problem.

switch.text: Applying a problem as an input can be useful in cases where this will resolve some variable, such as how d...

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 258px; height: 1px; padding-top: 3385px; margin-left: 300px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; font-weight: bold; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div:
Problem Interactivities
(like Interaction Levels, such as surfaces and boundaries and components, providing direct interactions with other structures)

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 593px; height: 1px; padding-top: 3565px; margin-left: 126px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div:
Solving a problem by its surface/direct/external interactions with other structures is useful in cases where you can apply structures to limit these interactions, to prevent the problem from causing outputs or taking inputs that increase the errors for other structures.
A biological corollary would be altering a surface protein/sugar/receptor of a molecule/cell to neutralize a pathogen.
Solving a problem by applying a boundary to change its interactions with other structures is useful in cases where you can apply structures to limit these interactions, to prevent the problem from causing outputs or taking inputs that increase the errors for other structures.
A biological corollary would be to apply a capsule or other boundary type to neutralize a pathogen.
Similar to these other problem formats, applying problem components also applies a core interaction function of "break" such as is used in common workflows like "break a problem into components (variables) or sub-problems", at which point other problem-solving structures like adjacent change combinations, interactive sequences, useful input/output sequences, organization structure, solution filters, perspective changes, and causal networks can be used on those components to create a solution structure. For example, structures like common error structures, unnecessary structures, and contradictions might be components of problems in general.

switch.text: Solving a problem by its surface/direct/external interactions with other structures is useful in ca...

a.text: Text is not SVG - cannot display
